entry.title: How to plan a trip to see Africa's Great Migration
entry.summary:
Africa‚Äôs Great Migration is a world-renowned wildlife phenomenon where more than a million wildebeest, along with countless zebras and gazelles, follow the rains across Tanzania‚Äôs Serengeti and Kenya‚Äôs Maasai Mara in a relentless quest for greener pastures. Each year, Africa‚Äôs Great Migration sees millions of wildebeest and zebra thunder across the sun-bleached savannah, drawn by instinct to cross crocodile-infested rivers where predators lie in wait. But beyond the chaos, this epic journey reveals a deeper, more complex tale of survival and symbiosis on the Serengeti stage.
This article was produced by¬†National Geographic Traveller¬†(UK).
To a soundtrack of thundering hooves and panicked brays, wildebeest plunge into the muddy Mara River, churning the water as sly crocodiles‚Ä¶

entry.title: The small Swiss town where people still vote by hands in the air
entry.summary:
For most of the year, big crowds are unusual in the Swiss town of Glarus. At the base of a dramatic point in the Alps called the Gl√§rnisch ridge, the hamlet is tranquil, largely undisturbed by the tourists who descend on the region‚Äôs picturesque areas. But every year there is one day‚Äîusually the first Sunday in May‚Äîwhere citizens of the canton gather en masse in the town square for a tradition that‚Äôs over 700 years old. Questions are boomed over the loudspeakers and thousands of people raise their hands in response. This is the Landsgemeinde‚Äîone of the world's oldest forms of direct democracy still in practice.¬†¬†
Meaning ‚Äúcantonal community assembly‚Äù in German, the Landsgemeinde dates back to medieval times. Glarus, with its population of around 41,000 people, is one of only two Swiss‚Ä¶

entry.title: Why Rome‚Äôs dolphins are fighting each other
entry.summary:
Rome, the Eternal City, is revered for its history, art, culture, and food. Yet, few people know that less than¬†an hour away, where the Tiber River flows into the Tyrrhenian Sea, there‚Äôs something that makes the area even more unique: a population of around 500 bottlenose dolphins.¬†
Now, a¬†recent study¬†shows that the dolphins are not only sick, but they‚Äôre fighting over food‚Äîand it‚Äôs due to human activity.¬†
The ‚ÄúCapitoline dolphins,‚Äù as researchers have named them, have inhabited the coast outside Rome for thousands of years, as shown by mosaics from the archaeological site of Ostia Antica that depict the dolphins stealing fish from fishermen's nets 2,000 years ago. Yet they‚Äôve only recently been closely studied, beginning in 2016.¬† Two male dolphins have an aggressive enco‚Ä¶

entry.title: Why this photographer made a camera lens out of glacial ice
entry.summary:
Artist Tristan Duke traveled to Svalbard, Norway, in 2022 to create camera lenses made from shards of pristine ice pulled from glacial waters. Tristan Duke uses Arctic ice and a unique technique to offer a fresh perspective on a world transformed by climate change.
Glacial ice is formed from¬†snow accumulating and compacting over millennia. As the pressure increases, crystalline layers are smoothed into one of the clearest substances found in nature. That alchemy‚Äîand the knowledge that climate change is causing glaciers to rapidly disappear‚Äîinspired 44-year-old artist Tristan Duke to create a photo lens out of glacial ice. ‚ÄúI just felt this real sense of urgency,‚Äù Duke says. He wanted to capture a glacier through its own ‚Äúeye,‚Äù as he puts it, like a self-portrait.
In the spring of 2022, Duke hauled hundreds of pounds of gear to Svalbard, Norway, including a giant tent camera that he designed himself and molds for shaping the ice into lenses. The tent functioned like a camera obscura: Duke would place a palm-size piece of ice in a hole in the canvas, projecting an image of the landscape inside the tent that would then be captured on a 42-by-100-inch negative.
Some of the photographs were clearer than he expected, but as the lenses melted, the accumulation of water produced its own effect. ‚ÄúPeople have told me that it looks like the world blurred through tears,‚Äù he says.
To contrast this Arctic sublime against a world on fire, he traveled through the American West to document wildfires and energy infrastructure with lenses created from locally sourced ice. He wants to invert the romantic gaze. ‚ÄúWe see a sort of fragile nature bearing witness to the unbridled and cataclysmic power of the human world.‚Äù undefined undefined A version of this story appears in the July 2025 issue¬†of¬†National Geographic¬†magazine.

entry.title: Britain‚Äôs first Black queen? The real story of Queen Charlotte
entry.summary:
When 17-year-old Sophia Charlotte of Mecklenburg-Strelitz caught her first glimpse of the London palace that was to be her home in 1761, she turned pale. She was set to become Queen of Great Britain and Ireland within hours, but she had never set foot in England or met her husband-to-be.
What happened next is the stuff of royal history, brought to recent light in Netflix‚Äôs limited series, Queen Charlotte: a Bridgerton Story fictionalizing the life of the timid German girl rumored to have been Britain‚Äôs first Black queen. But who was the real Queen Charlotte?
Born in 1744 in Mecklenburg-Strelitz, a duchy in what is now northern Germany, the princess had an unremarkable childhood in what other members of the European aristocracy considered to be a mediocre and provincial dukedom.‚Ä¶

entry.title: Try a detour on your next trip to these classic destinations
entry.summary:
Philadelphia's Magic Gardens is an art gallery meets community center on South Street. Detour destinations, aka lesser-known spots, are trending in travel for several reasons. Try one of these getaways that are less crowded and offer rich local experiences.
A recent Expedia travel trends report shows that, remarkably, 63 percent of travelers plan to include lesser-known spots in their travels this year, with destinations that offer locally rich experiences.
A detour destination doesn‚Äôt mean completely avoiding a popular destination. It can also involve a night or two in that tried-and-true destination, just with an alternate destination also worked into the plans, for reasons including lower costs and new experiences.
Just 15 minutes from busy Monterey, Carmel-by-th‚Ä¶

entry.title: Visiting Istanbul? Here‚Äôs where to eat
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
There‚Äôs no shortage of good reasons to visit Istanbul ‚Äî from its flagship attractions such as the Hagia Sophia and the Basilica Cistern to the seductive rhythms of its busier neighbourhoods and the tranquillity of its islands. Yet its standout feature is arguably its cuisine. This is a city that‚Äôs been home to an impressive, bustling dining scene for over two millennia ‚Äî and, while many travellers limit themselves to the prix fixe menus in the Historical Peninsula, there‚Äôs a greater culinary depth available to those willing to venture beyond the touristy kebab shops. Here are nine of the city‚Äôs best dining options ‚Äî restaurants that excite the locals and offer visitors something they‚Äôre unlikely to forget. ¬†
‚Ä¶

entry.title: How to lower stress in 5 minutes
entry.summary:
Feeling overwhelmed? You‚Äôre not alone. Between meetings, errands, and the endless scroll of everyday life, stress builds up fast‚Äîand it doesn‚Äôt just take a toll on your mood. It can disrupt your sleep, spike your heart rate, and weaken your immune system.
But here‚Äôs the good news: research shows that even small, low-effort actions can help your body reset. Here are six things you can do right now‚Äîand the science behind why they work.
Few things affect your nervous system as immediately‚Äîor as powerfully‚Äîas your breath. Studies show that deep breathing can lower blood pressure, slow your heart rate, and boost heart rate variability‚Äîa key marker of resilience. It also reduces cortisol, the stress hormone associated with a range of issues, including poor sleep and brain fog. Contro‚Ä¶

entry.title: An LED track, super shoes, and a suit made from Aeronodes
entry.summary:
7.65 seconds.¬†
That‚Äôs the amount of time that Kenyan Faith Kipyegon needs to shave from her world record time in order to become the first woman to run the mile in under 4 minutes.¬†¬†
Kipyegon, a three-time gold medalist, has spent months training for an exhibition on Thursday in Paris where she‚Äôll take a crack at the mythic sub-four barrier. An attempt, she says, to ‚Äúcement her legacy.‚Äù¬†¬†¬†
The event, dubbed Breaking4, is being staged by Nike, Kipyegon's sponsor. To help her make history, everyone from physiologists to shoe designers have rallied to find ways to help her trim every hundredth of a second possible‚Äîsome of which make the run ineligible for official world records.¬†¬†
It‚Äôs a tricky task. The mile is short enough that small benefits have little time to accrete ‚Ä¶

entry.title: UN urges renewed diplomacy on Iran nuclear deal, hails Tehran-Tel Aviv ceasefire as ‚Äòsignificant achievement‚Äô
entry.summary: A fragile ceasefire brokered by the United States between Iran and Israel appears to be holding, marking a tentative halt to a dangerous regional escalation that included airstrikes, retaliatory missile attacks and mounting civilian casualties.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Bold new initiative aims to strengthen and improve the UN, senior officials tell Member States
entry.summary: Member States heard on Tuesday how the UN is progressing with a new plan to ensure the world body remains effective, cost-efficient and responsive to the billions of people it serves.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Aftermath of Tripoli clashes puts Libya‚Äôs fragile stability to the test
entry.summary: Libya once again stands at a critical juncture in its political transition, after armed clashes erupted in Tripoli last month, further destabilising the country, the UN Special Representative for the country told the Security Council on Tuesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World News in Brief: T√ºrk speaks out on sexual violence, Brazil floods update, Nicaraguan human rights violations
entry.summary: Gender-based violence is rising - especially in conflict ‚Äì something which is a ‚Äúshameless repudiation of the basic rules of warfare,‚Äù according to the UN human rights chief¬†Volker T√ºrk.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: ‚ÄòStill reeling‚Äô: Myanmar quakes worsen humanitarian crisis in fractured country
entry.summary: Nearly three months after Myanmar‚Äôs strongest earthquake in a century, more than six million people remain in urgent need of assistance, as the disaster compounds a humanitarian crisis driven by years of conflict, political turmoil and mass displacement.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: SECURITY COUNCIL LIVE: Political Affairs chief hails Iran-Israel ceasefire as ‚Äòsignificant achievement‚Äô
entry.summary: The Security Council is meeting over the future of the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action put in place in 2015 to prevent Iran from weaponising its ambitious nuclear programme, which has been in effective limbo since the US withdrawal in 2018 and Iran‚Äôs rejection of parts of the deal. UN political affairs chief Rosemary DiCarlo described the US-brokered ceasefire overnight between Israel and Iran as a ‚Äúsignificant achievement‚Äù and ‚Äúan opportunity to avoid a catastrophic escalation and achieve a peaceful resolution of the Iran nuclear issue.‚Äù Follow our Meetings Coverage Section live coverage below and UN News app users can follow here.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Power to the people; funding community-led development in Somalia
entry.summary: A story of grassroots persistence in Somalia could serve as a powerful reminder of the impact of innovative financing mechanisms as the international community meets in Spain to discuss how to fund global sustainable development.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Resettlement changed her life. Now she‚Äôs fighting for others to have the same chance
entry.summary: Once a teenager without legal status or access to education, Madiha Ali Changezi is now speaking out as a living example of what refugee resettlement can achieve.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Guterres urges Iran and Israel to ‚Äòfully respect‚Äô ceasefire
entry.summary: The UN Secretary-General on Tuesday welcomed the ceasefire announcement between Iran and Israel which was announced on social media overnight by US President Donald Trump.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza: Over 400 Palestinians killed around private aid hubs, UN rights office says
entry.summary: At least 410 Palestinians have been killed by the Israeli military while trying to fetch from controversial new aid hubs in Gaza ‚Äì a likely war crime ‚Äì the UN human rights office, OHCHR, said on Tuesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: What time is it on the Moon? It‚Äôs all relative‚Ä¶
entry.summary: Telling the time on the Moon is more complicated than you might think, but answering the question is becoming more important amid a resurgent interest in lunar exploration. The UN is helping to ensure the Moon is governed in a coordinated and peaceful way, and agreeing on a time zone is a central element of international discussions.

entry.title: Taliban bride
entry.summary: Women in Afghanistan are prisoners in their own homes. This is the story of Marjan, married at 12 to a Taliban fighter - by Zala & Asad Nariman Read at Aeon

entry.title: Dine like in The Bear at these Chicago fine dining spots
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
From beef sandwiches to Michelin-star-seeking menus ‚Äî TV show The Bear‚Äôs fictional restaurant has given us a story arc that, in many ways, mirrors the real-life culinary history of the city it‚Äôs set in. Just as the Original Beef of Chicagoland was transformed from a sauce-splattered sandwich bar into the show‚Äôs titular fine-dining venture, so too has Chicago evolved from a meatpacking capital to one of America‚Äôs pioneering food cities.
One upon a time, fine dining in the Windy City mostly consisted of steak and potatoes. Then in 1987, Charlie Trotter opened his eponymous restaurant in Lincoln Park. Using French and Japanese techniques and lots of fresh vegetables, Trotter ‚Äî like The Bear‚Äôs chef, Carmy ‚Äî was determi‚Ä¶

entry.title: What is a heat dome? The science behind the weather phenomenon
entry.summary:
A sunbather rests in a chair in a park in Sutton Place, New York in 2013. This summer‚Äôs heat dome will bring triple-digit temperatures to millions of Americans. Extreme humidity and triple-digit temperatures are affecting around 250 million people across the United States. Here's the science behind the heat dome that‚Äôs stifling the nation.

entry.title: How a 102-year-old neurologist keeps his brain sharp
entry.summary:
According to neurologist Howard Tucker, there is a scientific basis for not retiring. That's why this 102-year-old is the world's oldest practicing doctor. Howard Tucker has been practicing medicine since 1947. Ahead of his 103rd birthday, the neurologist shares his thoughts on living a healthier life‚Äîand enjoying it, too.
At 102 years old, Howard Tucker is the world‚Äôs oldest practicing doctor‚Äîand he‚Äôs eagerly looking for new work since the hospital where he taught medical residents closed in 2022. ‚ÄúRight now, I‚Äôm out of a job,‚Äù Tucker says.
While he‚Äôs no longer seeing patients, Tucker‚Äôs resume speaks for itself. He received his medical doctorate in 1947 and completed his neurology residency in 1953. He served in the U.S. Navy during World War II and was the chief neurologist ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Humidity really has gotten worse in the last 40 years
entry.summary:
The sun rises behind the skyline of midtown Manhattan and the Empire State Building in New York City. This summer's high humidity is expected to be even worse in urban areas. As temperatures rise across the U.S., here‚Äôs what you need to know about high humidity and how it can affect you.
The first major heat wave of summer has enveloped much of the midwestern and eastern U.S. in a brutal ‚Äúdome‚Äù of record temperatures and high humidity. The dome phenomenon happens when weather conditions cause high pressure to remain stagnant, trapping bands of heat and humidity within a region for long periods of time.
Experts warn that heat-related illness, including heat exhaustion and heat stroke, pose significant risks over the coming days.

entry.title: Alaska‚Äôs untamed wilderness is about to get more accessible
entry.summary:
The Alaska Cabins Project aims to make traveling to Alaska's wilderness easier and more inclusive. A new project in the Chugach and Tongass National Forests will make overnights in Alaska‚Äôs wilderness less intimidating for travelers looking for ‚Äúsoft‚Äù adventures in the wild.
Overnighting in Alaska‚Äôs wilderness is about to get easier. The Alaska Cabins Project, a joint initiative from the Forest Service and the National Forest Foundation, will bring 25 new, easily reachable abodes to the untamed Tongass and Chugach national forests by 2027. Several have already opened‚Äîor will open‚Äîthis year.
The project marks a milestone for the state. ‚ÄúThis is the largest expansion of public use cabins on Alaska‚Äôs national forests in 50 years,‚Äù says Patrick Shannon, the NFF‚Äôs Pacific Northwest‚Ä¶

entry.title: The improbable city where ice cream is king
entry.summary:
When Shahrukh Shah was a boy, the small, dusty city of Gangapur, India, wasn‚Äôt known for much. It was an agricultural town, a hub for the region‚Äôs many farmers, and Shah‚Äôs family grew corn and wheat on three acres nearby. But farming was never easy on the plains of central Rajasthan‚ÄîIndia‚Äôs largest state and among its driest‚Äîand as Shah got older, it became tougher still, with the rainy seasons more erratic, droughts more frequent, and water for irrigation harder to come by.
Then, around 2014, when Shah was a teenager, his father decided to give up farming during the parched four-month summer in favor of the business that has since put Gangapur on the map: ice cream.
(8 ice cream styles from around the world.) https://interactives.natgeofe.com/high-touch/ngm-2507-India-ice-c‚Ä¶

author.name: Brian Kevin, Federico Borella, Michela Balboni

entry.title: 7 of the best bookshops to visit in the UK
entry.summary:
This port town indie store includes a ‚Äòstudy‚Äô with co-working desks and an upstairs cafe. Independent Bookshop Week was celebrated across the UK this June ‚Äî we‚Äôve selected four shops worth a literary pilgrimage.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
With summer bringing Independent Bookshop week to UK shores, we‚Äôre celebrating bookstores that are well worth travelling to. From a hilltop spot in York to a cool cafe hangout in London‚Äôs East End and far beyond, we‚Äôve selected independently run shops that continue to draw book-lovers to towns and cities across the UK and Ireland. Many of these have been recognised by the Independent Bookshop of the Year award, past or present, and all are lovely places to linger over a good read, graphic novel or open‚Ä¶

entry.title: This city rewards travelers‚Äîjust for being responsible
entry.summary:
Responsible travelers are rewarded through the fairly new CopenPay program after they engage in good deeds such as picking up trash in one of Copenhagen‚Äôs green spaces. With overtourism concerns hitting cities across Europe, this new initiative aims to encourage eco-friendly behavior by offering free or discounted food, drinks, and cultural experiences.
Imagine a city that rewards you for making sustainable choices‚Äîride a bike instead of driving to receive free admission to a museum, walk 5,000 steps to get a free cup of coffee, or collect trash from the harbor to earn a free kayak ride. That‚Äôs what Copenhagen is doing through its new CopenPay initiative.
CopenPay encourages visitors to make environmentally friendly choices in exchange for free or discounted local experiences,‚Ä¶

entry.title: What was the Scopes 'Monkey' Trial?
entry.summary:
Jock the monkey listens in on the Scopes 'Monkey' trial verdict in Washington DC on July 21, 1923. The Scopes trial was one of the most covered court cases in US history, and the first US trial to be broadcast on national radio. In 1925, a small-town trial became a national spectacle, pitting faith against science. Here's what to know about the lasting legacy of the Scopes 'Monkey' Trial.
Was Charles Darwin‚Äôs theory of evolution scientific fact or dangerous, anti-Christian heresy? In 1925, one young teacher became a target of a law outlawing teaching evolution in schools‚Äîand a central figure in the fight to teach evidence-based science.¬†
Twenty-four-year-old John T. Scopes didn‚Äôt remember if he‚Äôd actually taught evolution to his high school students in Rhea County, Tennessee‚Äî‚Ä¶

entry.title: Acknowledgments
entry.summary: This report is a collaborative effort based on the input and analysis of the following individuals. Moira Fagan, Research AssociateSneha Gubbala, Research AnalystJacob Poushter, Associate Director, Global Attitudes Research Dorene Asare-Marfo, Senior Panel ManagerPeter Bell, Associate Director, Design and ProductionJanakee Chavda, Associate Digital ProducerLaura Clancy, Research AnalystJonathan Evans, Senior ResearcherJanell Fetterolf, Senior ResearcherShannon Greenwood, Digital [‚Ä¶] The post Acknowledgments appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: About Pew Research Center‚Äôs Spring 2025 Global Attitudes Survey Results for the survey are based on a mix of telephone, face-to-face and online interviews conducted under the direction of Gallup, Langer Research Associates and Social Research Centre. The results are based on national samples, unless otherwise noted. Read more about our international survey methodology and [‚Ä¶] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Appendix: Classifying European political parties
entry.summary: Classifying parties as populist Although experts generally agree that populist political leaders or parties display high levels of anti-elitism, definitions of populism vary. We use three measures to classify populist parties: anti-elite ratings from the 2019 Chapel Hill Expert Survey (CHES), Norris‚Äô Global Party Survey and The PopuList. We define a party as populist when [‚Ä¶] The post Appendix: Classifying European political parties appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 3. Views of Zelenskyy
entry.summary: Across 25 countries, a median of 45% have confidence in Zelenskyy, while an identical share do not. Ratings vary widely, from 85% confidence in Sweden to 19% in Greece. The post 3. Views of Zelenskyy appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 2. Views of Russia and Putin
entry.summary: Across 25 countries, a median of 79% view Russia unfavorably and 84% lack confidence in Putin. Opinions differ by age, ideology and right-wing populist party support. The post 2. Views of Russia and Putin appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 1. Views of NATO
entry.summary: Majorities in 10 of 13 member nations surveyed have a positive view of NATO, though ratings have dipped in a few countries since last year. The post 1. Views of NATO appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: NATO Viewed Favorably Across 13 Member Nations
entry.summary: Ahead of the June 2025 NATO summit, international views of Putin and Russia remain negative, while Zelenskyy gets mixed ratings overall. The post NATO Viewed Favorably Across 13 Member Nations appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Smart glasses that track activity, emotion, and what you eat
entry.summary: For Tom‚Äôs Guide, Jason England reviews smart glasses by Emteq, which are equipped‚Ä¶ Tags: Emteq, glasses, Tom's Guide

entry.title: These are the first images from Earth‚Äôs giant new telescope
entry.summary:
Perched high in the foothills of Chile‚Äôs Andes mountains, a revolutionary new space telescope has just taken its first pictures of the cosmos‚Äîand they‚Äôre spectacular.¬†
Astronomers are excited about the first test images released from the Vera C. Rubin Observatory, which show the universe in unprecedented detail, from violent cosmic collisions to faraway nebulas.
‚ÄúIt's really a great instrument. Its depth and large field of view will allow us to take really nice images of stars, especially faint ones,‚Äù says Christian Aganze, a galactic archeologist at Stanford University who will use the observatory‚Äôs data to study the formation and evolution of the Milky Way. ‚ÄúWe are truly entering a new era.‚Äù
The observatory has a few key components: A giant telescope, called the Simonyi Su‚Ä¶

entry.title: Why Puerto Rico should be your next food destination
entry.summary:
Puerto Rico imports 85% of its food ‚Äî an issue that became even more apparent after Hurricane Maria. ‚ÄúTeaching people how to grow food, for us, that‚Äôs a rebel act,‚Äù says Efr√©n David Robles, owner of small, family-run farm Frutos Del Guacabo. The Caribbean island‚Äôs cuisine combines African, Indigenous and Spanish influences to create dishes of distinction.
More than 500 years of complex history shines through in Puerto Rico‚Äôs cuisine ‚Äî a dynamic mix of Spanish, African and Indigenous culinary traditions. Many of Puerto Rico‚Äôs most famous dishes focus on hearty starches, like plantain and yuca, infused with the herby flavours of the island‚Äôs favourite condiment, sofrito. Restaurants across the historic capital, San Juan, give a fine-dining twist to classic dishes such as toston‚Ä¶

entry.title: UN80 Initiative: What it is ‚Äì and why it matters to the world
entry.summary: In a world grappling with growing crises, deepening inequalities, and eroding trust in global institutions, the United Nations has launched an ambitious effort to strengthen how it serves people everywhere. The UN80 Initiative, unveiled in March by Secretary-General Ant√≥nio Guterres, is a system-wide push to streamline operations, sharpen impact, and reaffirm the UN‚Äôs relevance for a rapidly changing world.

entry.title: Human Rights Council hears concerns over displacement, genocide risks and migrant trafficking
entry.summary: On day six of the¬†59th Session of the Human Rights Council (HRC) in Geneva, the Council heard urgent updates on rising internal displacement driven by organised crime, escalating genocide risks and the trafficking of women in the domestic work sector.

entry.title: Tobacco control efforts protect three-quarters of the world‚Äôs population, WHO report finds
entry.summary: Tobacco use still claims over seven million lives a year, the World Health Organization warned on Monday, calling for greater efforts to limit its use amid rising interference from the global tobacco industry.

entry.title: Senior envoy warns Iran-Israel conflict is deepening crisis in Afghanistan
entry.summary: Afghanistan is already grappling with immense humanitarian and economic challenges and growing instability in the wider region following airstrikes by Israel and the United States in Iran is compounding the situation, the UN‚Äôs top envoy in the country told the Security Council on Monday.

entry.title: UN condemns ‚Äòheinous‚Äô terrorist attack at Damascus church that killed dozens
entry.summary: The United Nations has condemned a suicide bombing on Sunday at a Damascus church that killed at least 25 worshippers, including women and children during mass, as a ‚Äúheinous crime‚Äù.

entry.title: Asia is warming twice as fast as the rest of the world
entry.summary: In April 2024, China broke the average temperature record that month. The following month, it was the same - and then again in August. And September. And November.

entry.title: Yemen: Nearly half the population facing acute food insecurity in some southern areas
entry.summary: The food security situation in Government-controlled areas of southern Yemen is dire, with nearly half the population facing acute food insecurity and struggling to find their next meal.

entry.title: Iran-Israel crisis: IAEA chief calls for access to damaged nuclear sites
entry.summary: After surprise US bombing raids on Iranian uranium enrichment facilities over the weekend, the head of the UN-backed nuclear watchdog on Monday appealed for immediate access to the targeted sites to assess the damage that is likely ‚Äúvery significant‚Äù.

entry.title: For the UK's best fish and chips, look no further than Cornwall
entry.summary:
Today, Cornwall's fish and chips offering ranges from beloved local chippies to Michelin-acclaimed kitchens. A crisp portion of fish and chips remains the ultimate coastal comfort food ‚Äî and Cornwall is home to some of the UK‚Äôs best, available at everything from traditional chippies to pioneering Michelin-recognised restaurants.
This article was produced by¬†National Geographic Traveller¬†(UK).
Come summer, nothing quite hits the spot like a generous serving of fish and chips eaten beside the Cornish coast. Whether wrapped in vinegar-soaked paper ‚Äî perhaps enjoyed on a harbour wall ‚Äî or served in a pub garden accompanied by a chilled local cider, this iconic British dish never fails to satisfy. Traditionally made with cod or haddock, deep-fried to a golden crisp and paired wit‚Ä¶

entry.title: Where to go for a beginner's gravel-biking adventure in Scotland
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Galloway is a bit of Scotland that‚Äôs often overlooked by visitors. Across the border from England, this southwestern region (officially Dumfries and Galloway) is often bypassed in the rush north: to Glasgow, Loch Lomond & The Trossachs National Park, and the Highlands. Yet, the place couldn‚Äôt be more Scottish. This was the stomping ground of Robert the Bruce and William Wallace. Its wee towns are practical and unfussy, and there are castles left over from the English wars. The scenery ‚Äî mountains ballooning from heather moors, swathes of pine forest, streams where otters tumble ‚Äî has grandeur, sweep and romance. Put it all together, and it‚Äôs no surprise the area has caught the eye of travellers on gravel bikes, an incr‚Ä¶

entry.title: INTERVIEW: Visitors to Expo 2025 appreciate ‚Äòpositive vision‚Äô of UN
entry.summary: Visitors to Expo 2025, a world fair currently being held in Osaka, Japan, appreciate the ‚Äúpositive vison‚Äù of a shared global future promoted by the United Nations; that‚Äôs according to Naomi Ichikawa, Director of the UN Pavilion.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza: UN warns of ‚Äòweaponised hunger‚Äô and growing death toll amid food chaos
entry.summary: The top UN humanitarian official in the Occupied Palestinian Territory has issued a stark warning over the deepening crisis in Gaza, where civilians are being killed daily while trying to access food, water and medical care.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: US strikes on Iran‚Äôs nuclear sites ‚Äòmarks perilous turn‚Äô: Diplomacy must prevail, says Guterres
entry.summary: The UN Secretary-General Ant√≥nio Guterres told an emergency meeting of the Security Council on Sunday that massive overnight strikes by the United States on Iran‚Äôs nuclear facilities only increase the risk of a wider war and ‚Äúserious damage to the international order.‚Äù

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: SECURITY COUNCIL LIVE: ‚ÄòDiplomacy must prevail‚Äô over Iran following US military intervention, urges Guterres
entry.summary: The UN Secretary-General told the Security Council on Sunday that the bombing of Iran‚Äôs nuclear sites by the United States marks a ‚Äúperilous turn‚Äù, warning that the region cannot endure yet another ‚Äúcycle of destruction.‚Äù Ant√≥nio Guterres said the must be an immediate ceasefire and returned to ‚Äúserious, sustained negotiations.‚Äù We‚Äôll have live updates from our Meetings Coverage¬†team below and app users can follow here.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Guterres condemns deadly attack on peacekeepers in Central African Republic
entry.summary: The UN Secretary-General has strongly condemned a deadly attack on peacekeepers serving with the UN peacekeeping mission in the Central African Republic, or CAR, which claimed the life of a Zambian peacekeeper and left another wounded.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: What is financing for development?
entry.summary: According to the United Nations, the world needs an extra $4 trillion every year to tackle some of the world‚Äôs biggest challenges ‚Äì ending poverty and hunger, fighting climate change, and reducing inequality.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.summary: In an age marked by conflicts, disease, dysfunction and mental health challenges, yoga offers a steady, time-trusted path to help find calm and harmony within ‚Äì and without.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN reiterates call for urgent de-escalation amid Iran-Israel conflict, worsening Gaza crisis
entry.summary: Senior UN officials reiterated an appeal for urgent restraint on Saturday as conflict spiral between Israel and Iran, amid a wider regional crisis exacerbated by Israel‚Äôs war in Gaza and the worsening humanitarian situation facing Palestinian civilians.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Why is the manosphere on the rise? UN Women sounds the alarm over online misogyny
entry.summary: A growing network of online communities known collectively as the ‚Äúmanosphere‚Äù is emerging as a serious threat to gender equality, as toxic digital spaces increasingly influence real-world attitudes, behaviours, and policies, the UN agency dedicated to ending gender discrimination has warned.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: From the Global South to the stars: A new space race
entry.summary: Once the exclusive domain of a handful of technologically advanced countries, outer space is now within the reach of emerging nations from the Global South, as costs fall and technology becomes more widely available.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Explore Italy's most famous coastline with these timeless adventures
entry.summary:
Italy's most sought-after destination is ripe for exploring ‚Äî you just have to know where to look. From a clifftop walking trail to a subterranean Roman villa, via a martini worthy of a film star ‚Äî here‚Äôs how to make the most of your time on Italy‚Äôs prettiest shoreline.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
A landscape of extreme verticality, where gelato-hued houses and terraced gardens cling to sea-facing cliffs, this strip of Southern Italy is justly famed for its beauty. Long a source of inspiration for writers and artists ‚Äî from 19th-century composer Richard Wagner to Patricia Highsmith, who set her novel The Talented Mr Ripley here ‚Äî the entire area is a designated UNESCO World Heritage Site. Ravello, Amalfi and Positano are its most celebra‚Ä¶

entry.title: The city of 700 languages
entry.summary:
Seke is an endangered language originally spoken in five villages of northern Nepal, but its future may depend on a handful of vertical villages: apartment buildings in the middle of Brooklyn, New York.‚ÄØ‚ÄØ
How did a little-documented, oral-only language used by no more than 700 people in the high Himalaya come to the concrete jungle? Rasmina Gurung, in her 20s one of Seke‚Äôs youngest speakers, learned the language from her grandmother in the village but soon moved to the country‚Äôs capital, Kathmandu, and eventually New York‚Äîwhere she estimates at least a quarter of her people have ended up. Here they join speakers of dozens of other endangered languages from across the Himalaya, all forming new communities while getting by in an ever evolving mix of Nepali, Tibetan, English, and their o‚Ä¶

entry.title: Try these essential dishes on your next trip to Greece
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Greek food sings of the summer ‚Äî it‚Äôs best enjoyed outside, from mainland mountaintops to island beaches. Mezze spreads celebrate punchy purple olives, garlicky dips and herb-sprinkled cheese, while salads of sun-ripened tomatoes, tangy feta and fragrant oregano are perfect with just-landed grilled fish or slow-stewed legumes cooked in outdoor ovens following recipes that date back to antiquity. Here are the nine essential dishes to try when in Greece. Lily Bellos sits at her Corfu home in Benitses as she showcases her pastitsada, or ‚Äòla pastizzada‚Äô, as the island‚Äôs Venetian colonisers called it. It's a dish that‚Äôs been representative of Corfu for hundreds of years. Pastitsada is slow-cooked meat ‚Äî beef, rabbit,‚Ä¶

entry.title: Transylvania may hold the secret to a long and happy life
entry.summary: On a chilly twilit evening,¬†three men sit around a wood table in the parsonage of a 13th-century church in Transylvania. Outside are ducks, beehives, and a shaggy white dog that we can hear barking at something in the growing dark. Warmed by a wood-burning stove, the men sip tea and nibble savory, pretzel-shaped cookies, and talk about their home, Kar√°csonyfalva. https://interactives.natgeofe.com/high-touch/ngm-2207-romanian-village-map/builds/main/html/_graphic.html Transylvania. Is there a better known place-name and a lesser known place? (Perhaps Timbuktu.) Even when all of Europe was wilder, Transylvania stood for its wildest edge. This is why Bram Stoker saw fit to use it as a setting for¬†Dracula,¬†despite never setting foot there. It‚Äôs a place where Saxons, Huns, Turks, Tart‚Ä¶

entry.title: Statin drugs are an Internet villain. Do they deserve it?
entry.summary:
The cholesterol-lowering drug Simvastatin. Like other statins, this drug reduces the levels of low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol in the body. Over 40 million Americans currently take statins. Cholesterol-lowering medicines are some of the most commonly prescribed, effective drugs. Influencers on TikTok have other ideas.
Inside the average doctor‚Äôs office, statins aren‚Äôt controversial; they‚Äôre a crucial lifesaving tool used to lower dangerously high cholesterol levels, reducing risk of heart attack. But on social media, the drug is often villainized, painted as a poison pill, or a symptom of a diseased medical system. Recently, influencers have claimed that statins cause more harm than good and have endless side effects. Others take even bigger swings, claiming that the¬†fun‚Ä¶

entry.title: What fracking is doing to the Earth‚Äîand to our bodies
entry.summary: A methane gas flare erupts at the Bakken Oil Fields in Mountrail County, North Dakota. Research attributes 40% of this century‚Äôs atmospheric methane increase to fracking. Beneath layers of ancient rock, a high-pressure process is reshaping the modern energy landscape. As fracking expands across the globe, so does the growing debate around its impact. What is fracking? You may have heard about the effects this oil and gas extraction technique have on the environment, but its impacts extend far beyond that.¬†¬† Between 2007 and 2016, oil production in the United States increased¬†75 percent, while natural gas production incre‚Ä¶

entry.title: 7 unmissable UK beaches to visit this summer
entry.summary:
Somewhere in the UK's four nations, your perfect beach awaits. Across 7,700 miles of coastline spread between the four nations of the UK are family favourites, wildlife wonderlands, historical strands and bays of astonishing wild beauty. Here are seven of the best beaches to visit this summer.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Don‚Äôt believe anyone who says the United Kingdom is a poor comparison to the likes of Australia, or South Africa when it comes to beaches. What the country lacks in palm trees or exotic wildlife, it makes up for in the sheer variety of its coastline. Somewhere in its four nations, your perfect beach awaits: places with birdlife or wild beauty and destinations where fish and chips with your feet in the sand is an essentia‚Ä¶

entry.title: The 4 biggest mysteries the new Vera Rubin Observatory could solve
entry.summary:
On a mountaintop in Chile's sprawling Atacama Desert, a new telescope has turned its mechanical eyes to the heavens, stargazing with unprecedented intensity. The Vera C. Rubin Observatory will take hundreds of pictures, every night, for the next 10 years.
Astronomers around the world are absolutely giddy over Rubin, which is named for the late astronomer who discovered evidence for the existence of dark matter. The observatory's mirrors will collect a tremendous amount of light, catching the glint of very faint, faraway objects. That light will be focused into the largest digital camera on the planet, a 3,200-megapixel camera the size of an SUV, capable of producing pictures from multiple wavelengths of light.¬†
Instead of focusing on one segment of sky for hours at a time, Rubin ‚Ä¶

entry.title: What makes the North Sea‚Äôs waves so treacherous
entry.summary:
Sometimes, the North Sea just decides to take a shot at you. Henk Buitjes knows what it‚Äôs like.
Once, it happened at night in rough weather. The Dutch shrimp fisher was hauling his nets aboard when out of the corner of his eye he saw the wave. It stood out. Bigger than all the others, it was about to hit the rear of his fishing ship, a beam trawler.
The wave smashed into one of the ship‚Äôs two beams, long horizontal poles that hang over the side and suspend nets in the water.
The incredible force of the wave battered the unlucky beam. It bowed the beam, leaving the net hanging slack and almost impossible to retrieve. That, Buitjes knew, was extremely dangerous. The net might wrap itself around the ship‚Äôs propeller or become ensnared on seabed debris.

entry.title: What it's like to celebrate midsummer in Sweden
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
As my Swedish army bike rattles down the last hill, I place a hand on the basket to secure my Midsummer contributions: two king-size sausage rolls and a green bean and orange salad. The wide-open fields of southern Sweden‚Äôs fertile S√∂dersl√§tt plain, yellow with rapeseed flowers, stretch out to my right, while to my left, the Baltic Sea has just slipped out of sight, having been there for most of my 20-minute ride from the station.
When I turn into the gravel drive, Malin and Christian‚Äôs century-old brick villa, K√§llbacken, meaning ‚Äòhill with a spring‚Äô, is already clattering with preparations. Malin and her seven-year-old daughter Edith have been out picking the flowers and greenery that will decorate the midsommar‚Ä¶

entry.title: When 'Jaws' invaded Martha‚Äôs Vineyard, 50 years ago
entry.summary: Director Steven Spielberg on the set of Jaws. 50 years after the legendary movie was filmed, locals reminisce about the time Hollywood came to town. JAWS DIDN'T JUST CHANGE cinematic history. The summer blockbuster also transformed Martha‚Äôs Vineyard. Long before the Clintons, Obamas, Oprah, and Larry David moved in to make it the starriest second-home locale on the Eastern Seaboard, the tranquil New England island was everything Hollywood wasn‚Äôt. In fact, prior to director Steven Spielberg and crew setting up cameras to create the definitive shark thriller, the last movie to shoot there was in the silent era. ‚ÄúJaws put us on the map,‚Äù explains Martha‚Äôs Vineyard Museum research librarian Bow Van Riper. ‚ÄúIt was what really kicked off the world coming to the Vineyard, and ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Celebrate Amsterdam's 750th birthday with these fun-filled events
entry.summary:
Amsterdam‚Äôs ‚Äòdancing houses‚Äô get their nickname from the way they seem to sway and dance, creating an optical illusion. Twenty-four-hour neighbourhood festivals, a nine-mile-long street party and a whole year of revelry ‚Äî Amsterdam is pulling out all the stops for its 750th birthday.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
This year, Amsterdam marks its extraordinary 750-year journey from medieval fishing village to global cultural capital with a festival programme as dynamic and diverse as the city itself. Everyday spaces will be transformed in unexpected ways ‚Äî on the longest day of the year, locals will reclaim the traffic-heavy A10 ring road for a nine-mile street party featuring culture, sport and even 20 weddings. entry.title: Ukraine: Security Council hears of escalating attacks, diplomatic developments
entry.summary: The UN Security Council met on Friday to discuss the situation in Ukraine, where intensified fighting continues, affecting new areas and prompting further displacement.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: ‚ÄòA fire no one can control‚Äô: UN warns of spiralling Iran-Israel war
entry.summary: The world stands on the edge of catastrophe, United Nations Secretary-General Ant√≥nio Guterres warned on Friday, as Israel‚Äôs military campaign inside Iran intensifies and strikes on nuclear facilities threaten to trigger a catastrophe.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN Peacebuilding Commission ‚Äòmore needed than ever‚Äô amid rising conflict
entry.summary: Former Liberian President Ellen Johnson-Sirleaf and other senior officials from across the world have spoken about how international support was critical to putting their countries on the path to peace.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: WHO warns of a health financing emergency
entry.summary: The world is facing a health financing emergency, according to Dr. Kalipso Chalkidou, Director for Health Financing and Economics for the World Health Organization (WHO).

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: For too long, ‚Äòunbound horrors‚Äô have unfolded in Sudan
entry.summary: Hostilities continue to escalate across Sudan‚Äôs¬†North Darfur and¬†Kordofan regions, with reports of civilian casualties, sexual violence, abductions and looting, the UN human rights chief warned on Friday, describing the consequences as disastrous.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: From Syria, UN refugee chief calls for greater solidarity with displaced people
entry.summary: Although record numbers of people ‚Äì over 122 million worldwide ‚Äì have been uprooted due to war, violence and persecution, their ability to find safety and support is threatened more than ever.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza horrors continue as the weakest succumb to injuries and disease
entry.summary: Death and suffering in Gaza are ever-present and the enclave's people now have little choice but to risk their lives to fetch aid supplies, UN agencies said on Friday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: MIDDLE EAST CRISIS: Live updates for 20 June
entry.summary: One week since the Israel-Iran conflict erupted, diplomatic efforts to end the war are ramping up in Geneva today as foreign ministers from France, Germany, the UK and the European Union prepare to meet their Iranian counterpart. In New York, meanwhile, the UN Security Council is also set to discuss this latest worrying escalation, against the backdrop of the ongoing emergency in Gaza. We'll be covering these developments and more across the UN system today. UN News¬†app users can follow here.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: ‚ÄòWe are at a point of no return‚Äô: grave violations against children surge for third year
entry.summary: Last year, 41,370 grave violations against children were documented and verified by the United Nations, according to the Secretary-General's annual report on children in armed conflict, released on Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World News in Brief: Global investment plunges, hurricane season in Haiti, rising cholera and hunger in South Sudan
entry.summary: Global investment fell a full 11 per cent to $1.5 trillion last year ‚Äì it‚Äôs a huge blow for developing nations, the UN trade agency, UNCTAD, said on Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World Refugee Day: telling their stories
entry.summary: Of the 122 million people globally displaced by persecution, violence or human rights violations, 42.7 million are refugees who have fled across borders, according to new data from the UN refugee agency (UNHCR).

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Long after the guns fall silent, conflict-related sexual violence leaves lasting scars
entry.summary: Sexual violence in conflict is a tactic of war, torture and terror. It does not only devastate survivors but also tears apart families and communities. The trauma, shame and stigma are borne by victims, not perpetrators ‚Äì echoing across generations.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN warns of mounting humanitarian toll as Israel-Iran hostilities continue
entry.summary: As deadly missile exchanges between Israel and Iran enter a second week, the United Nations is sounding alarm over the growing toll on civilians, warning of mass displacement and regional instability.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Monitoring Iran and promoting peaceful nuclear use ‚Äì IAEA role explained
entry.summary: Just days before Israel launched a bombing campaign against Iran, the UN watchdog agency monitoring Iran‚Äôs nuclear activities warned that the country was in violation of its non-proliferation commitments.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Development is ‚Äòthe first line of defense against conflict,‚Äô Guterres tells Security Council
entry.summary: Of the 700 million people worldwide living in extreme poverty, 40 per cent live in conflict-affected or fragile settings and this is on track to worsen, UN Secretary-General Ant√≥nio Guterres told the Security Council on Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza: As last fuel supplies run out, aid teams warn of catastrophe
entry.summary: More than 100 days into Israel‚Äôs complete fuel blockade in Gaza, UN agencies still in the shattered enclave warned on Thursday that vital services are only ‚Äúhours away‚Äù from shutting down.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: But the flowers remain
entry.summary: Join a Romanian family as they prepare for winter in the mountains and reflect on the richness of a slower way of life - by Aeon Video Watch at Aeon

entry.title: The unseen
entry.summary: Our crisis of work and technology is one in which too many people feel that nobody sees them as a fellow human being - by Allison J Pugh Read at Aeon

entry.title: The Golden Records tell the story of Earth. Here‚Äôs what they say.
entry.summary:
The Golden Record carried by Voyager 1 and 2. Photographs of Jupiter by Voyager 1 on March 24, 1979 and Uranus by Voyager 2 on January 24, 1986. In 1977, NASA launched two 12-inch gold-plated copper disks filled with the sounds of children's laughter, heartbeats, and bird calls. Is their time in space running out?
In 1977, NASA launched Voyagers 1 and 2 from Cape Canaveral, Florida into space to embark on a grand tour of the far reaches of our solar system. Mounted on board each probe was a 12-inch gold-plated copper disk‚Äîa cosmic ‚Äúmessage in a bottle‚Äù engraved with sights, sounds, and depictions of life on Earth, collectively known as the Golden Records‚Äîon the slim chance some far-off alien civilization might discover them. And in Disney and Pixar‚Äôs animated film Elio, in theaters‚Ä¶

entry.title: Were there sinister motives behind founding Liberia?
entry.summary:
Faced with injustice in the land of their enslavement, oppressed people might find the offer of a new country, with the chance for freedom and prosperity, attractive. During the early 1800s in the U.S., however, the idea of establishing a colony of Black Americans in Africa was deeply controversial among freedmen‚Äîpeople of African descent who had gained freedom from enslavement‚Äîand freeborn Black people.
The reasons centered on the self-serving motives of many of the project‚Äôs promoters: It was supported by, among others, pro-enslavement figures. Although it led to the founding of Liberia‚Äîthe world‚Äôs second ever Black republic‚Äîthe new state later practiced violence against Indigenous Africans.
Most free Black people saw themselves as Americans, participating in the economy of t‚Ä¶

entry.title: Forget the road trip‚Äîthese national parks are best visited by train
entry.summary:
A passenger train rolls through the unforgiving desert landscape as seen through some beautiful blooming Ocotillo cactuses. Trains are an accessible way to see some of America‚Äôs national parks. With popular national parks still searching for the answers to congestion, train travel is a practical solution‚Äîand a unique adventure.
Driving to and through the most popular U.S. national parks can be a hassle‚Äîfrom parking to long lines at the entrance gates. For many parks, train travel may be the stress-free answer for parkgoers who don‚Äôt want to drive. Locomotives can move hundreds of people along a rail bed less than 5 feet wide, which can drastically reduce traffic woes. Riders can enter these parks without a coveted vehicle reservation while enjoying vistas often inaccessible by road‚Ä¶

entry.title: These dolphins have orca friends‚Äîbut may have an ulterior motive
entry.summary:
Pacific white-sided dolphins swim off the coast of British Columbia. Dolphins and porpoises in this region have been spotted swimming alongside a population of killer whales known as northern resident orcas. Scientists have theories about why. Scientists have documented what might be the first case of friendly interactions between killer whales and smaller cetaceans. Here's what they think is going on.
A pod of Dall‚Äôs porpoises sped toward an adult orca, swimming under and around her for a few minutes before getting ‚Äúbored‚Äù and moving on to her companions‚Äîa mother orca with a young calf. As soon as the porpoises appeared, the calf seems to have gotten excited, speeding up and trying to catch the porpoises. The mother eventually got frustrated, but ‚Äúthe calf looked like it was havin‚Ä¶

entry.title: There‚Äôs a deeper meaning behind Juneteenth food traditions
entry.summary:
Juneteenth is celebration of Black history and culture, where communities gather and eat, as seen here at a festival at Malcolm X Park in West Philadelphia. Grilled meats, watermelon, and hibiscus are often served on the holiday not only to bring communities together, but to honor Black history.
While now recognized as a national holiday, Juneteenth has always been embedded in the local culture of Galveston, Texas, where the last group of enslaved Africans were freed by Union soldiers two years after the Civil War ended. The holiday is still cherished among city locals who celebrate the day their ancestors were finally given their freedom.
(Juneteenth is America‚Äôs second Independence Day‚Äîhere‚Äôs why.)
At its core, Juneteenth represents the community coming together over mu‚Ä¶

entry.title: This Reporter Exposed the Civilian Toll of US Airstrikes. Her Warning: Be Ready for a More Hostile World
entry.summary: The Pulitzer Prize winning investigative reporter Azmat Khan is known for her rigorous reporting on civilian casualties in war, the impact of US airstrikes, and for exposing systemic failures in military and government accountability.

entry.title: The unlikely comeback of America‚Äôs most endangered songbird
entry.summary:
On the dry prairies of the Sunshine State, there‚Äôs a tiny, camouflaged bird known as the Florida grasshopper sparrow. Each one weighs about as much as three U.S. quarters yet has to survive against a backdrop of torrential floods, herds of stomping cattle, and waves of ravenous fire ants.
Not to mention the humans. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve lost over 90 percent of their habitat,‚Äù says¬†Fabiola ‚ÄúFabby‚Äù Baeza-Tarin, a senior conservation ecologist with a Tampa-based consulting firm known as Common Ground Ecology.¬†
Florida grasshopper sparrows and many other organisms rely on the dry prairie for their entire life cycles, not even leaving to migrate, but humans have increasingly rendered the space inhabitable by clearing and draining it to make way for development, ranching, and intensified agricult‚Ä¶

entry.title: This is the first ever confirmed skull of a Denisovan
entry.summary:
The "Dragon Man" skull was discovered in Harbin, China in 1933 by a local laborer, but remained hidden away until 2018. A new analysis now finds its very likely to be a Denisovan. Finally, we can put a face on a Denisovan.
In the summer of 2021, a team of five Chinese researchers stirred up some controversy by suggesting that an unusual skull unearthed in northeastern China belonged to a previously unknown species they thereby officially described as Homo longi, nicknamed ‚ÄúDragon Man.‚Äù (Both names were inspired by the Long Jiang Dragon River region where it was found.) Soon afterwards, the team was contacted by paleogeneticist Qiaomei Fu of the Institute of Vertebrate Paleontology and Paleoanthropology in Beijing, who asked if she could try and get DNA from the skull.¬†¬†
Back ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Relationships outside an appropriate age range
entry.summary: People tend to marry or partner with those closer to their age. However, some venture outside the typical range. Tags: age, relationships

entry.title: How the Motor City reinvented itself as an unlikely star of the arts
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Detroit‚Äôs story is often told in three acts. First came its rise. Once the beating heart of America‚Äôs manufacturing industry, it was Motor City‚Äôs assembly lines ‚Äî the first of their kind in the world ‚Äî that set the wheels in motion for an automotive revolution that brought motoring to the masses. Jobs and prosperity followed and by the 1950s, Detroit was among the richest cities in the world, its skyline stacked with art deco icons like the Guardian Building, which acted as beacons of industry.
Next, act two: the fall. In the second half of the 20th century, automation in manufacturing and the outsourcing of production to cheaper locations ushered in widespread factory closures and layoffs. White flight to the subu‚Ä¶

entry.title: Marijuana doubles your risk of cardiovascular death
entry.summary:
As marijuana has become increasingly mainstream in the United States, researchers are raising concerns about its impact on heart health‚Äîadding to a growing list of potential health risks that already include psychosis and schizophrenia.
In a new paper published in the journal Heart, researchers analyzed data from 24 previous studies and found that cannabis use is associated with a significantly increased risk of major cardiovascular events‚Äîincluding ‚Äúmyocardial infarction, a stroke, and increase in cardiovascular death,‚Äù says Emilie Jouanjus, a clinical pharmacologist at Centre Hospitalier Universitaire de Toulouse in France and a researcher on the project.¬†
The findings, based on health data from 200 million people worldwide‚Äîincluding in the United States‚Äîshowed that cannabis us‚Ä¶

entry.title: ‚ÄòSmart grid‚Äô helps accelerate energy transition in Indonesia
entry.summary: Renewable energy plants are being built across Indonesia, but for their electricity to reach consumers, a modernization of the electricity grid is necessary.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Ahead of UN summit, countries finalise landmark ‚ÄòCompromiso de Sevilla‚Äô
entry.summary: UN Member States have reached agreement on the outcome document for the Fourth International Conference on Financing for Development, to be formally adopted at an upcoming summit in Sevilla, Spain ‚Äì though without the participation of the United States, which withdrew from the negotiations and announced it will not attend the conference.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Human Rights Council hears alarming updates on executions in Iran and global civic space crackdown
entry.summary: On the third day of the 59th Session of the Human Rights Council (HRC), the spotlight turned to reports on rising executions in Iran and the increasing repression of civic space around the world amid a wave of elections.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Guterres renews call for Israel-Iran ceasefire
entry.summary: UN Secretary-General Ant√≥nio Guterres said on Wednesday he remains ‚Äúprofoundly alarmed‚Äù by the ongoing military escalation between Israel and Iran, as the sides continued to trade airstrikes.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Power of football inspires team effort towards development goals
entry.summary: The power of football to inspire fans to take positive action for a healthier planet and a fairer society is taking centre stage at Expo 2025 in Osaka, Japan ‚Äì a world fair focused on building a sustainable global future.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Make midwives universally accessible and save millions of lives, WHO urges
entry.summary: Almost 4.5 million maternal, stillborn and newborn deaths were recorded in 2023. What if there was a clear path to saving 83 percent of these people? To saving 3.7 million mothers, unborn children and babies annually?

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN rights office ‚Äòhorrified‚Äô by deadly violence at Gaza food distribution sites
entry.summary: As the pall of starvation hangs over Gaza, UN agencies have sounded the alarm over deadly violence at food distribution points, where over 400 Palestinians have reportedly been killed in recent weeks while trying to access desperately needed humanitarian aid.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN relief chief calls for solidarity, with humanitarians ‚Äòliterally under attack‚Äô
entry.summary: With the humanitarian sector ‚Äúunder-funded, overstretched, and literally under attack‚Äù as crises continue in Gaza, Sudan and beyond, international support is needed more than ever, the UN‚Äôs top aid official said on Wednesday in Geneva.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Civilian deaths in conflict are surging, warns UN human rights office
entry.summary: Civilian deaths in conflict surged by 40 per cent last year, according to new data released by the UN human rights office (OHCHR) with already marginalised groups facing disproportionate levels of discrimination.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Iran-Israel crisis: UN rights office appeals for urgent de-escalation
entry.summary: As the Iran-Israel crisis continued into a sixth day on Wednesday, the UN deputy human rights chief Nada Al-Nashif called for urgent talks to end the ongoing missile attacks between Tehran and Tel-Aviv.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.summary: A tender portrait of the bond between a mother and child, captured over the course of a visitation at a rural Virginia prison - by Aeon Video Watch at Aeon

entry.title: Weekend visits
entry.summary: A tender portrait of the bond between a mother and son, captured over the course of a visitation at a rural Virginia prison - by Aeon Video Watch at Aeon

entry.title: The unexpected ways Ozempic-like drugs might fight dementia
entry.summary:
They were designed to treat diabetes, then prescribed for weight loss, and now‚Äîas researchers are finding‚Äîthey might hold the secret to staving off Alzheimer‚Äôs, too.
She can see the difference. Yazhou Li, a neuroscientist at the National Institute of Aging in Bethesda, Maryland, studies the effects of different drugs on brain impairments including traumatic brain injury, Alzheimer‚Äôs disease, stroke, and Parkinson‚Äôs disease. Working in the laboratory of neuroscientist Nigel Greig, Li and her colleagues test drugs on injured cells in dishes, run mice and rats through mazes, look at their brains. They are trying to find out if treatment with certain drugs might reduce the devastating effects of dementia or brain injury.‚ÄØ
And the latest drug they‚Äôre testing? Seems to work. The damage‚Ä¶

entry.title: A memory researcher on extreme amnesia cases and imagined futures
entry.summary:
Harvard cognitive psychologist Daniel Schacter‚Äôs work has underpinned a sea change in how we think about memory; namely, that the act of remembering might be the key to how we imagine our futures.
We tend to think of human memory as if it's one of those old steel filing cabinets: some information gets stashed inside, and when the time comes, we hope we can find it by flipping through the tabs on a few billion neuron-supported manila folders. But the truth, as science has learned‚Äîand continues to learn‚Äîis that memory is more than just the attic of our minds. We‚Äôre realizing that it‚Äôs a foundational part of how we interpret and imagine our futures. And few have done more work to unlock this powerful reframing of human memory than cognitive psychologist Daniel Schacter.
What he and ‚Ä¶

entry.title: The neuroscientist ‚Äòzapping‚Äô away unwanted memories
entry.summary:
‚ÄúEternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind‚Äù might not be fiction for much longer, if memory researcher Steve Ramirez gets his way. 
Think of your happiest memory. A wedding, your child‚Äôs birth, or maybe just a perfect night out with friends. Sit with it for a moment. Remember the details. What were you wearing? What did it smell like? How did it make you feel?
Now do the opposite. Think of a sad memory‚Äîthe loss of a loved one, getting laid off, or a painful breakup. Sit with this one too.
Which would you rather keep?¬†
Of course, you want the happy memory, the one that made you feel good and joyful about life. Yet, the painful ones linger for years and sometimes decades, like bruises beneath the surface. If you could choose, would you keep them‚Äîor delete them entirely? ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Yes, you can teach yourself to forget. And here's why you should
entry.summary:
Science shows you can break memories as well as make them‚Äîyou just need to know how.
Earlier this year, 20-year-old Vishvaa Rajakumar memorized 80 random numbers in 13.5 seconds‚Äîroughly six numbers per second. This feat helped him win the Memory League World Championship, a tournament that pushes memory to its extremes. In another challenge, participants memorized the order of an entire shuffled deck of cards.
Even if your memorization skills wouldn‚Äôt win an international competition, having an above-average memory is considered a prize. Nearly three-quarters of adults say they play games like crossword puzzles not only for fun, but to improve their memory. After all, having a good memory is associated with sharpness and intelligence, while aforgetfulness is a quality linked to s‚Ä¶

entry.title: A Greek revival is underway along the Athenian Riviera
entry.summary:
Astir Beach is popular with locals and visitors alike for its high-end amenities and crystal clear water. The region was popular in the 1960s but lost some sheen as Santorini and Mykonos took flight. Today, Athens‚Äô glittering coastline has been reimagined.
In its late 1960‚Äôs heyday, there was arguably nowhere on Earth as discreetly glamorous as the Athenian Riviera.
A nearly 40-mile stretch of sun-kissed coastline stretching from the port of Piraeus to the southernmost point of Attica at Cape Sounion, the Athenian Riviera has been a popular destination for decades. Celebrities, socialites, and locals seeking a mix of serenity and solitude would come to unwind, basking in the crystalline waters and palm-fringed beaches. Stories of a bikini-clad Brigitte Bardot seen dancing bare‚Ä¶

entry.title: They sing to remember: The power of memory choirs
entry.summary:
These men and women may have dementia, but when they take the stage, they sing like they've never missed a beat. And now cognitive scientists are wondering: can song unlock a new way to treat cognitive disorders?
The performers enter Sundin Music Hall arm in arm, lavender scarves draped around their pressed white shirts. It‚Äôs nearly showtime, but the eager singers‚Äîa constellation of community members, some young but many old and bespectacled with gray hair‚Äîfind a few minutes to hug and chat, clinging tightly to their binders of music. These are the 68 members of the Giving Voice St. Paul Chorus, ready for their spring concert.
They‚Äôve been preparing every Tuesday for the past four months, learning to belt out favorites like ‚ÄúSingin‚Äô in the Rain‚Äù and ‚ÄúBridge Over Troubled Water.‚Äù ‚Ä¶

entry.title: What is the summer solstice? Here‚Äôs what you need to know.
entry.summary:
A group of people in the early morning of the summer solstice in Wiltshire, England. The northern hemisphere celebrates the summer solstice as the longest day and shortest night of the year. Once a year, an astronomical alignment ushers in this seasonal change. Like its winter counterpart, the summer solstice is celebrated across the world‚Äîand shrouded in myth.
This year, the Northern Hemisphere's summer solstice occurs on June 20 at 10:42 p.m. EST. South of the Equator, this same moment marks the beginning of summer. Solstices occur at the same time around the world, but their local times vary with time zones.¬†
Traditionally, summer and winter solstices helped mark the changing of the seasons‚Äîalong with their counterparts, the spring and autumnal equinoxes. ‚Ä¶

entry.title: He remembers nothing. She remembers everything
entry.summary:
In the archives of the brain, our lives linger or disappear.
There is a 41-year-old woman, an administrative assistant from California known in the medical literature only as "AJ," who remembers almost every day of her life since age 11. There is an 85-year-old man, a retired lab technician called "EP," who remembers only his most recent thought. She might have the best memory in the world. He could very well have the worst.
"My memory flows like a movie‚Äînonstop and uncontrollable," says AJ. She remembers that at 12:34 p.m. on Sunday, August 3, 1986, a young man she had a crush on called her on the telephone. She remembers what happened on Murphy Brown on December 12, 1988. And she remembers that on March 28, 1992, she had lunch with her father at the Beverly Hills Hotel. She rem‚Ä¶

entry.title: How photo overload might be warping our ability to remember
entry.summary:
Taking thousands of pictures on our phones means never losing a moment‚Äîbut it‚Äôs also complicating how our minds shape our memories.
When Lavania Oluban looks at photos from her childhood, the memories feel incomplete. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs hazy around the edges‚ÄîI‚Äôm filling in missing pieces of the puzzle with a memory that‚Äôs not quite real,‚Äù she says.
Oluban, 37, has only a handful of birthday photos from when she was young. But her seven-year-old-son, Arlo, has ‚Äúeasily 200,‚Äù captured by different attendees on their smartphones. ‚ÄúPractically every single second of his life is documented,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúArlo‚Äôs almost got a virtual reality representation of an event because there are so many pictures and videos. I think for him, it‚Äôs quite vivid.‚Äù
In 2023, people around the world took an estimat‚Ä¶

entry.title: How smelling roses could help you make stronger memories
entry.summary:
A scent, a touch, or a sip can be just what you need to lock an important moment into your mind forever.
If hearing an old song or getting a whiff of freshly sharpened pencils instantly carries you back to high school, you‚Äôre familiar with the link between your senses and memory.¬†
When a sensory experience spontaneously evokes an autobiographical memory, it‚Äôs often called the Proust Effect, named for French author Marcel Proust who described how the experience of eating a madeleine instantly transported him back to childhood in his novel In Search of Lost Time.
‚ÄúThe senses are critical for memory because they‚Äôre at the intersection between our environment, our experiences, and our memory system,‚Äù says Susanne Jaeggi, a professor of psychology, applied psychology, and mus‚Ä¶

entry.title: Use this ancient technique to remember (almost) anything
entry.summary:
Embraced by the world‚Äôs best memory athletes, the ‚Äúmethod of loci‚Äù can also help the rest of us strengthen our recall, heal from trauma, and stave off cognitive decline.
In Orlando, Florida, a dozen seniors gather in a YMCA twice a week. Some push walkers, others roll in on wheelchairs. After some light exercise and corny jokes, they get down to the real workout‚Äîflexing their memory muscles. Most are battling early-stage dementia, hoping to hold onto their memories a little longer.
They‚Äôre learning an ancient technique called the method of loci, which transforms any familiar space into a storage system for new information. Want to remember your grocery list? Link milk to your sister‚Äôs senior photo in the living room‚Äîvisually, and in a way that feels almost absurd. Maybe imagine i‚Ä¶

entry.title: The diet that could make your brain 7 years younger
entry.summary:
What you put in your body can have a big impact on what you keep in your head.
Many people worry about losing their mental sharpness as they get older. That‚Äôs not surprising given that we‚Äôre all hearing about rising rates of dementia as the population ages: A study in the January issue of Nature Medicine suggested that by the year 2060, the number of adults in the U.S. who will develop dementia is likely to double to a million people. That‚Äôs a club no one wants to join. Fortunately, science is showing that healthy eating habits can have a powerful impact on protecting cognitive function and memory.
Developed in 2015 by researchers studying the effects of diet on brain function and cognitive decline, the (aptly named) MIND diet combines the Mediterranean diet‚Äîwith its focus on‚Ä¶

entry.title: Could orienteering be the next big thing in travel?
entry.summary:
Orienteering originated in Scandinavia as an aspect of military exercise, but quickly evolved and became more broadly popularised due to the region‚Äôs ‚Äòright to roam‚Äô policies. As the UK‚Äôs ‚ÄòRace Across the World‚Äô TV series becomes increasingly popular, orienteering could see a surge in global interest.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Land in an unfamiliar country and race from checkpoint to checkpoint with no phone, no flights and limited funds. This is the premise of the BBC‚Äôs Race Across the World, now in its fifth season and achieving record-breaking viewing figures for the BBC. It‚Äôs orienteering on a grand scale ‚Äî an activity that‚Äôs slowly been attracting more interest both in the UK and abroad, perhaps partly thanks to the hugely popular ‚Ä¶

entry.title: ‚ÄòHate speech is poison in the well of society,‚Äô says Guterres
entry.summary: Hate speech is a warning sign and a driver of violence, UN Secretary-General Ant√≥nio Guterres said ahead of¬†Wednesday‚Äôs International Day for Countering Hate Speech.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Israeli actions in Palestinian territories constitute war crimes, Human Rights Council hears
entry.summary: The ongoing crises in the Occupied Palestinian Territory and Sudan are in the spotlight this week at the UN Human Rights Council (HRC) in Geneva.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN condemns deadly Russian strikes on Ukrainian capital as civilian toll mounts
entry.summary: At least 14 civilians were reportedly killed and more than 100 injured in Kyiv overnight into Tuesday, as Russian drone and missile strikes struck multiple Ukrainian cities in one of the heaviest nights of bombing in months.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: ‚ÄòSyria simply cannot withstand another wave of instability,‚Äô Security Council hears
entry.summary: A senior UN official has warned against the impact of regional escalation on Syria as the country continues on the path to political transition following the overthrow of the Assad regime last December and nearly 14 years of devastating civil war.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Afghan women face near total social, economic and political exclusion
entry.summary: In the past decade, the UN has bemoaned the chronically low level of participation by Afghan women and girls in decision-making bodies and in secondary and higher education.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: More Gazans killed trying to get food, healthcare near to ‚Äòfull disaster‚Äô
entry.summary: Gaza‚Äôs health system is at breaking point, overwhelmed time and again by scores of people killed or injured near aid distribution sites, the UN World Health Organization (WHO) said on Tuesday.

entry.title: Can drinking Coke really help with migraines?
entry.summary:
Whenever I feel a migraine coming on, I reach for something with caffeine in it, such as a large Coke.
I‚Äôm among the¬†estimated 14 to 15 percent of people who live with migraines, which is a major cause for global ill health, leading to many missed days of work and doctor‚Äôs appointments. Although there are currently a number of pharmaceutical treatments available for migraines, many long-term migraineurs have their go-to home remedies that they swear by.¬†
Drinking caffeinated soda, such as a Coke, is one of those hacks‚Äîand I was curious to find out whether scientists agree the ingredients in soda can indeed help take the edge off an on-coming migraine. As it turns out, they do‚Äîor at least they agree it helps for some people: ‚ÄúThere¬†is some medical reasoning behind it,‚Äù says Kather‚Ä¶
