entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: The American Trends Panel survey methodology Overview Most of the data in this report comes from Wave 162 of the American Trends Panel (ATP), Pew Research Center‚Äôs nationally representative panel of randomly selected U.S. adults. The survey was conducted from Feb. 3 to 9, 2025. A total of 9,544 panelists (including 1,787 Catholics) responded out [‚Ä¶] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Acknowledgments
entry.summary: Pew Research Center is a subsidiary of The Pew Charitable Trusts, its primary funder. This report is a collaborative effort based on the input and analysis of the following individuals. Find related reports online at pewresearch.org/religion. Primary researchers Patricia Tevington, Research AssociateGregory A. Smith, Senior Associate Director, Religion Research Research team Alan Cooperman, Director, Religion [‚Ä¶] The post Acknowledgments appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 7. Catholic connections
entry.summary: About three-in-ten are ‚Äúcultural‚Äù or former Catholics, or have other ties to the faith. Read about these groups and why some say they left the religion. The post 7. Catholic connections appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 6. Views of sexual abuse and misconduct in the Catholic Church
entry.summary: Most think reports about sexual abuse in the church reflect ongoing issues, but they don‚Äôt think the problem is unique to the Catholic Church. The post 6. Views of sexual abuse and misconduct in the Catholic Church appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 5. Profile of U.S. converts to Catholicism
entry.summary: Six-in-ten converts to Catholicism were raised Protestant. Converts tend to be more Republican than current Catholics raised in the faith. The post 5. Profile of U.S. converts to Catholicism appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 4. Profile of Hispanic Catholics in the U.S.
entry.summary: About a third of U.S. Catholics are Hispanic. They‚Äôre more likely than White Catholics to practice some devotions, but less likely to take Communion at Mass. The post 4. Profile of Hispanic Catholics in the U.S. appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 3. Catholic parish life, culture and community
entry.summary: Most see their parish priests favorably, and many engage in their parish beyond going to Mass, according to Pew Research Center. The post 3. Catholic parish life, culture and community appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 2. Catholic practices and devotions
entry.summary: U.S. Catholics‚Äô religious observance varies widely. Find out how often they take Communion, pray the rosary and attend a Traditional Latin Mass. The post 2. Catholic practices and devotions appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 1. Essentials of Catholic identity
entry.summary: Most say having a personal relationship with Jesus is essential to Catholic identity. Roughly half say this about Marian devotion and helping the poor. The post 1. Essentials of Catholic identity appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 47% of U.S. Adults Have a Personal or Family Connection to Catholicism
entry.summary: Nearly half of U.S. adults are connected to Catholicism. Read about going to Mass, Communion, confession and more. The post 47% of U.S. Adults Have a Personal or Family Connection to Catholicism appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: How to spend the perfect day in Cartagena
entry.summary:
In Getsemani, Plaza de la Trinidad is home to street music, fast-food vendors and locals sitting kerb-side with a drink. Coffee, cumbia and Caribbean spirit: here‚Äôs how to make the most of your day in this northern Colombian city.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Cartagena ‚Äî a lively city on Colombia‚Äôs northern Caribbean coast ‚Äî has always moved to the rhythm of its own drum. It‚Äôs where the jaunty beats of cumbia music fill a UNESCO-stamped historical quarter, where innovative cocktail bars and trendy coffeeshops are never too far away and where some of Latin America‚Äôs most talented chefs use indigenous ingredients to create exquisite Colombian-Caribbean dishes. Throw in ample green space and a live music scene that lasts until the early hour‚Ä¶

entry.title: The sublime ways humans are changing the Earth
Was this woman the Cersei Lannister of medieval London?
entry.summary:
Illustration from the end of the 13th century of a woman hammering a stake through a man's head. Ela Fitzpayne was a powerful aristocrat who offended the Archbishop of Canterbury and was ordered to do a "walk of shame." She may also have orchestrated the murder of her alleged lover, old letters reveal.
The 1337 murder of the priest John Forde in the heart of medieval London was especially gruesome: one attacker slit Forde's throat with a dagger while two others stabbed him with "long knives" in the belly. He was then left to bleed to death.
Violent crimes often happen in hidden places, but Forde's murder was designed to be seen, says a criminologist who has uncovered new documents that shed light on the motivations behind the killing.
‚ÄúThis was very much the Fifth Avenue ‚Ä¶

entry.title: From Himalayan melt to drowning shores, children lead the climate fight
entry.summary: From the high Himalayas down to sea level, climate change is no longer a distant threat for children in Nepal and the Maldives ‚Äì it is a daily struggle: landslides tear through mountain villages washing away homes and farms, while rising seas surge over island shorelines, threatening to swallow entire communities.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: DR Congo: Human rights violations could amount to war crimes, UN experts say
entry.summary: In the eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), Rwandan-backed rebels, Congolese troops, and allied militias have all committed human rights abuses, some possibly amounting to war crimes, the UN¬†High Commissioner for Human Rights said in Geneva on Monday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Guterres to launch life-saving campaign strengthening mine action worldwide
entry.summary: The UN Secretary-General is set to launch a global campaign to boost support for disarmament and mine action.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UNHCR forced to make deep cuts, despite rising needs worldwide
entry.summary: The UN refugee agency (UNHCR) announced on Monday that it is cutting global staffing costs by around 30 per cent, following a comprehensive review of its activities, spending, staffing and structure, prompted by major funding shortfalls.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Without urgent funding, global hunger hotspots are set to grow, UN warns
entry.summary: Since conflict erupted in Sudan, more than a million people have fled to neighbouring South Sudan, seeking refuge from escalating violence that has displaced 12.4 million people and plunged over half the Sudanese population into food insecurity.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: ‚ÄòBehind each crisis, people are suffering,‚Äô T√ºrk tells Human Rights Council
entry.summary: Eighty years after the United Nations was established to end war, uphold fundamental human rights and promote justice and international law, those founding principles are increasingly under threat, the UN‚Äôs human rights chief warned on Monday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Brutal cuts mean brutal choices warns UN relief chief, launching ‚Äòsurvival appeal‚Äô
entry.summary: Facing the most severe funding shortfall in the history of humanitarian aid, UN relief chief Tom Fletcher on Monday announced a ‚Äúhyper-prioritised‚Äù appeal for $29 billion to meet urgent global needs.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: MIDDLE EAST CRISIS: Live updates for 16 June
entry.summary: After a weekend of massive strikes and counter-strikes between Tel Aviv and Tehran, the UN's human rights chief, Volker T√ºrk on Monday condemned the violence and echoed wider calls for a negotiated end to the attacks. Meanwhile in Gaza, aid workers report that mobile communications networks continue to be cut in the shattered enclave. We'll be covering these developments and more across the UN system and beyond today, thanks for joining us. UN News app users can follow our live coverage here.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Program Director
entry.summary: The Global Investigative Journalism Network (GIJN) is looking for a Program Director to plan, lead, develop, and implement cutting-edge programs to foster the practice of investigative journalism across the globe. This full-time position will be part of GIJN‚Äôs management team, working to advance GIJN‚Äôs mission of supporting and strengthening investigative journalism worldwide ‚Äî with special [‚Ä¶]

entry.title: Experience the revival of this old-school Barcelona neighborhood
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
In Barcelona‚Äôs leafy Poblenou district, Pablo Pulido, an Argentinian ceramicist and jazz musician, points to the sky outside his narrow workshop‚Äôs open doorway when I ask why he moved here. ‚ÄúWe liked the light principally,‚Äô he tells me, ‚Äúand the closeness to the sea.‚Äù The bright Mediterranean sun floods in through the shop‚Äôs large windows, bouncing off the whitewashed walls to illuminate the mauve and yellow bowls and cups that line the shelves.
Despite his beige work apron, 42-year-old Pablo looks as well manicured as a matinee idol. He opened Kema two years ago with his partner Daiana Nu√±ez Schneider, a Uruguayan ceramicist and industrial designer. Theirs is just one of a new influx of galleries, studios and ind‚Ä¶

entry.title: Europe‚Äôs iconic train route faces fresh competition
entry.summary:
London St Pancras Highspeed (LSPH), the company responsible for the London station and the high-speed track to Folkestone, has drawn up plans to triple capacity at the notoriously congested station. Several train companies are vying to run services across the channel, adding new routes to the continent and ending Eurostar‚Äôs monopoly.
This story was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Passengers travelling to Europe by rail could see a raft of new train operators in the coming years. Eurostar ‚Äî which has always had a monopoly on services between London and Paris, Brussels and Amsterdam ‚Äî now faces the biggest threat of competition since it launched its first train through the Channel Tunnel in 1994. With the promise of more choice and lower prices, could this be ‚Ä¶

entry.title: 7 of the best wild swimming spots in the UK
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
There‚Äôs no better way to immerse yourself in nature than by going wild swimming. Every spot tells its own story: tidal pools fed by Scottish mountains leave your skin humming; river estuaries in Cornwall carry the scent of salt and oak; and in London, ponds are hangouts for locals looking to escape the city streets. Here, we round up seven of the most scenic, whether you‚Äôre looking for somewhere to go with your family or a wild adventure. They‚Äôre as beautiful as they are grounding, so take your time. And don‚Äôt forget to bring a flask; one of the best things about cold water is warming up again.
Set at the foot of the Black Cuillin mountains, a 20-minute walk from the Glenbrittle car park, these tumbling pools loo‚Ä¶

entry.title: How to experience northern Somerset without a Glastonbury ticket
entry.summary:
Glastonbury Tor has scenic steps with views over the Somerset Levels and into the neighbouring counties of Wiltshire and Dorset. The legendary music festival is just one reason to visit an area many are calling ‚Äòthe new Cotswolds‚Äô ‚Äì a hotbed of rural creativity home to some of the UK‚Äôs finest food.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
For decades, Somerset was chiefly famous for three things ‚Äî cider, cheddar cheese and ‚Äòscrumpy and western‚Äô band The Wurzels, whose musical homage to the combine harvester landed them a 1976 number one. Glastonbury Festival‚Äôs rise to prominence gradually shifted the dial on the county‚Äôs profile ‚Äî taking it from agricultural to alternative and, latterly, decidedly cool. Those who visit today will find it a delightful ‚Ä¶
